awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope for Force Measurement, Single-Molecule Manipulation and Other Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs. Professor Jaroslaw Drelich from Michigan Technological University and colleagues are acquiring an atomic force microscope (AFM). An AFM is a powerful tool to look at single molecules on a surface. It operates through an atomically sharp tip attached to an extremely soft cantilever that can sense forces at tiny atomic levels (pico-newton forces). Utilizing the forces between tip and a molecule, AFM can even be used to manipulate single molecules moving them to desired locations.  Using this information, projects measure the mechanical strength of single covalent bonds. This can lead to practical applications, for example, preparing better quick-response and moisture-resistant smart adhesives. Adhesion forces between materials for civil engineering application can be investigated. The research enabled by the AFM will have broad impacts in areas such as health, energy, environment and national security, and even the economy. Faculty, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate researchers in at least 16 research groups at Michigan Tech are trained to use this powerful instrument.

This atomic force microscope enhances research and education in areas by measuring van der Waals and magnetic forces between the tip and surface; the rupture force of non-covalent interactions between molecules and tip, and the scission force of covalent bonds in a molecule anchored between the tip and surface. Applications to projects include monitoring enzyme catalysis in real-time, and performing surface charge microscopy of biological cells. The microscope is used in the study of quick-response and moisture-resistant smart adhesives, and adhesion forces between materials for civil engineering applications. In other projects the shape and surface characteristics of atmospheric particles and atmospheric processing of black carbon are studied. The lattice structures of proteoglycan-galectin-3 cross-linked complexes are imaged and the ligand binding force of galectin-3 is measured.

MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope for Force Measurement, Single-molecule Manipulation and Other Applications

Michigan Technological University purchased an MFP-3D AFM instrument from Asylum Research and installed in the multi-use facilities of the university's Applied Chemical and Morphological Analysis Laboratory (ACMAL), in a room with reduced noise and vibrations.  Several ACMAL assistants and senior personnel were trained in the operation of the instrument, they in turn train and assist the post-graduate and graduate users with the operation of the instrument and interpretation of the AFM results. ACMAL personnel have additionally written and deployed a standard operational procedure for the AFM and developed a training package for new users.

Using this new AFM instrument, several research teams from across campus, from both engineering (materials science and engineering, biomedical engineering, chemical engineering, mechanical engineering, civil engineering) and scientific (chemistry, biology, physics) disciplines are advancing their interdisciplinary research projects on nanotechnology, surface chemistry, molecular engineering, biology, biomedical, chemical and mineral processing engineering. For example, using the AFM instrument, Michigan Tech researchers are now investigating the surface functionalization of carbon materials, the surface chemical oxidation of iron surfaces for understanding water surface chemical oxidation and corrosion mechanisms, and the growth of metal and metal oxide nano and meso structures on carbon-based surfaces using bottom-up surface chemical approaches, including the potential impact of these nanostructures and nanomaterials on performances of heterogeneous catalysts, thin film semiconductor materials or plasmonics (Figure 1). Further, researchers also investigate fundamental interfacial interactions on nano-structured and nano-topographic synthetic and natural materials, including the examination of ligand-driven lattice structures of human and plant-origin proteins that play roles in cell signaling. Among many accomplishments, elucidation of the mechanism of action of a bioactive substance named hemolysin-X or HelyX (extracted from a plant species) is worth mentioning.  HelyX kills cells by forming pores on the cell membranes. This bioactive substance is currently used to prepare erythrocyte ghost cells, a potential tool for delivering molecular cargo and for studying cell membranes (Figure 2).

The AFM instrument has been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate programs at Michigan Tech. Students from varying scientific and engineering disciplines are exposed to the new state-of-the-art instrumentation during laboratory hands-on activities and arranged campus demos focusing on quantum chemistry, nanotechnology, and interfacial and intermolecular interactions, igniting the students? interest in advanced science and technology (Figure 3). Outreach activities with the AFM instrument occur during Michigan Tech?s Summer Youth Programs, as well as during open houses and other events for visitors throughout the entire academic year. These events, targeted at middle- and high-school students, provide a platform for recruiting talented and underrepresented students to Michigan Tech.

In summary, the new AFM instrument broadens interdisciplinary research and educational activities and strengthens interdisciplinary research collaborations on molecular engineering and nanotechnology among research groups from various scientific and engineering disciplines across the Michigan Tech campus. With this new AFM, the researchers are capable of imaging surfaces at high-resolution in both air and liquid at precisely controlled temperature, and accurate force measurements at the single-molecule level, manipulating single-molecules with the AFM tip with high levels of control.
